item.title:
While hens are generally considered tame animals, a menace to their eggs or chicks can turn them in very aggressive beings.
This is one putying a stop to a sparrowhawk's attempt to snatch one of her chicks.

item.title: 🐘 Growing up in Japan, Satou didn’t immediately fall in love with science, but she did love animals. As an undergraduate, she spent a summer in Africa doing field work counting animals in the wild. (2/8)
item.description: 🐘 Growing up in Japan, Satou didn’t immediately fall in love with science, but she did love animals. As an undergraduate, she spent a summer in Africa doing field work counting animals in the wild. (2/8)
item.content:encoded: 🐘 Growing up in Japan, Satou didn’t immediately fall in love with science, but she did love animals. As an undergraduate, she spent a summer in Africa doing field work counting animals in the wild. (2/8)

item.title: 🧠 Satou loved being in the field and enjoyed the work, but she yearned to know more about animal behavior beyond just watching them. That desire led Satou to study neuroscience and her current research combining behavioral and brain science. (3/8)
item.description: 🧠 Satou loved being in the field and enjoyed the work, but she yearned to know more about animal behavior beyond just watching them. That desire led Satou to study neuroscience and her current research combining behavioral and brain science. (3/8)
item.content:encoded: 🧠 Satou loved being in the field and enjoyed the work, but she yearned to know more about animal behavior beyond just watching them. That desire led Satou to study neuroscience and her current research combining behavioral and brain science. (3/8)

item.title:
Satou’s lab seeks to understand how the brain generates behavior by asking why animals behave in a certain way and then modeling the behavioral strategies they evolved. The team looks for neural circuits that produce these strategies. (4/8)
Satou Lab ➡️ https://t.co/zQ6KsTiiQ6 https://t.co/65Xb2WIrJ8

item.title: 💬 “I like that problems in science can be very challenging, and I don’t mind breaking my routine to solve them. When we see unexpected results, I get very excited and start looking for possible explanations. That is my peaceful moment, and I’m never bored doing science.” (5/8)
item.description: 💬 “I like that problems in science can be very challenging, and I don’t mind breaking my routine to solve them. When we see unexpected results, I get very excited and start looking for possible explanations. That is my peaceful moment, and I’m never bored doing science.” (5/8)
item.content:encoded: 💬 “I like that problems in science can be very challenging, and I don’t mind breaking my routine to solve them. When we see unexpected results, I get very excited and start looking for possible explanations. That is my peaceful moment, and I’m never bored doing science.” (5/8)

item.title: 🥼 Satou says she was drawn to Janelia for its reputation developing molecular tools to study the brain and for its unique structure, with small labs and encouragement to try risky ideas. (6/8)
item.description: 🥼 Satou says she was drawn to Janelia for its reputation developing molecular tools to study the brain and for its unique structure, with small labs and encouragement to try risky ideas. (6/8)
item.content:encoded: 🥼 Satou says she was drawn to Janelia for its reputation developing molecular tools to study the brain and for its unique structure, with small labs and encouragement to try risky ideas. (6/8)

item.title: “I also feel effort has been made to make Janelia diverse and inclusive, which I think fosters great science as well as respect for all members of our community," Satou says. (7/8)
item.description: “I also feel effort has been made to make Janelia diverse and inclusive, which I think fosters great science as well as respect for all members of our community," Satou says. (7/8)

item.title:
🤿 Beyond the lab, Satou is looking forward to exploring the natural world outside Janelia with her dog. She also likes scuba diving and is excited about having easier access to the Caribbean so she can go diving there. (8/8)

item.title:
Cyanotriazole compounds can rapidly cure trypanosome infections in mice, a new study finds. The results bring the possibility of eradication and effective management of many neglected tropical diseases.
